STORM

STORytellying and Metaphors Ontology

Our Conclusions

Tracing universal narrative patterns in Shakespearean metaphors has been an interesting challenge. We found metaphors to be connected with narrative theories through location (Hegel's stages), main characters and turning points. We present below our findings with graphs representing data retrieved from our ontology.

Hegel's stages and metaphors

We examined the metaphors connected to theories somehow related to the narrative structure. More specifically, all the metaphors reflecting initial lack were found in the thesis, as expected, since the particular theory wants every story beginning with a lack of something, which the hero tries to address. Most of the metaphors related to the dialogue function of exposure of background information were also located in the thesis, which seems reasonable since the audience is always in need of contextual information at the beginning of a story. Metaphors reflecting change were distributed throughout the plays, a finding which agrees with the theory according to which change functions as a device that allows a story to unfold. In the antithesis/midpoint, we found most of the metaphors referring to ordeals, as anticipated by Yorke, who argues that the action peaks at this point of the story thanks to techniques like ordeal and change.

Protagonists, characters and themes

All or most of metaphors related to initial lack and internal conflict were used by the protagonists (Macbeth in Macbeth and Orlando in As You Like It). In general, most of the metaphors were articulated by the main characters (Macbeth, Lady Macbeth, Orlando, Rosalind). We also found a high quantity of metaphors (out of all metaphors somehow related to a theme) to be evoking the dominant themes of each play: power, politics and remorse in Macbeth and love and family in As You Like It

Dominant themes and main characters

Having identified the dominant themes of each play and the quantity of metaphors evoking them, we sought the speakers using these metaphors and discovered that in most cases they were the main characters.

Source domains: Macbeth vs As You Like It

Using the classification of metaphors in terms of their source domains, we explore the similarities and differences between metaphors in tragedy and comedy. It is worth mentioning that the number of metaphors in As You Like It is higher than in Macbeth. The source domains of the metaphors revolve around (Health, Nature, Living Entity, War, Physical Object) and in this graph we demonstrate the number of metaphors belonging to ach theme in the two plays. One can observe significant thematic differences in comedy and tragedy, like the predominance of the theme of nature in the source domains of the metaphors in Macbeth .

The differences in space

If we consider again the Hegel's theory about Thesis, Antihesis and Synthesis, is it possible to see differences in the location of metaphors in Comedy and Tragedy. As we could see the amount of metaphors in the Thesis is the same for Comedy and Tragedy, while in Antithesis we see a difference between the two plays. The Antithesis is the central part in a work and it's the point in which we have a change from a previous order (Thesis) to a new one (Synthesis), it's a moment in which we experience the subversion of the normality. It's quite interesting to notice that in this particular point we only have 5 metaphors in Macbeth, but we have 10 of them in As You Like It: in the Aristotele's Poetica the philosphos expressed the opinion thet the metaphors are ontologically complex and connected to the concept of mimesis and abstrction, and for their nature strictly connected more with the Tragedy than the Comedy, which is more concrete and connected to Similitudes. We already saw that the number of metaphors, in our case, is higher in Comedy, and that seems to be against Aristotele's point of view, but if we connect this data with the Hegel's theory we could have a surprising new perspective. Thesis as we said presented a situation of normality, and the amount of metaphors is the same in the two plays, but the real part that would start to define the nature of the play is the peripetia or Antitesis, in which however we have the a sort of subverted reality, particularly in commedy it's the moment of the absurd. In this perspective it's meaningful that the higher number of metaphors in Antithesis are placed in As You Like It, while in the Synthesis we have the restauration of the order and the number of metaphors is minor than in Macbeth.

The differences in themes

Considering Greiman's Theories about Isotopy we were quite interested in analizing again the themes in the plays, but this time from the storytelling poin of view. We noticed that we have diametrical differences between Comedy and Tragedy in terms of themes. There are not themes expressed in Macbeth that were exposed in As You Like It, excepting for the main theme of Politics, but taken from two different perspectives: in Macbeth has the connotation of Tiranny while in As You Like It as Usurping the throne.

References

  • Felluga, Dino. "Modules on Greimas: On Plotting." Introductory Guide to Critical Theory. https://cla.purdue.edu/academic/english/theory/narratology/modules/greimasplot.html
  • Greimas, A., Collins, F., & Perron, P. (1989). Figurative Semiotics and the Semiotics of the Plastic Arts. New Literary History, 20(3), 627-649.
  • Lakoff, G. and Johnson, M. (1980) Metaphors we live by. Chicago, IL: University of Chicago Press.
  • Meister, J. (2011) Narratology | The Living Handbook Of Narratology. Retrieved from: [Accessed 18 October 2020].
  • Pozzato, M. P. (2020). Introduction to the theory of narrativity [PowerPoint presentation]. Retrieved from https://virtuale.unibo.it/course/view.php?id=8085
  • Propp, Vladimir ([1928] 1968). Morphology of the Folktale. Bloomington: Indiana UP
  • Yorke, J. (2014). Into the Woods: A Five Act Journey into Story. New York, NY : The Overlook Press.
